Award.AwardTitle: Solution Theories and Scaling Limit Problems in Stochastic Partial Differential Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
In modern physics and other areas of science many problems have random components and are modeled by equations or systems of equations that are probabilistic. An important part of understanding the physics is knowing whether, or under what conditions, these equations have solutions. The principal investigator will further develop methods to study these types of equations. He will also organize conferences and develop courses on this topic.

Stochastic partial differential equations (SPDEs) arise from extremely important models in areas such as statistical physics, quantum field theory and fluid mechanics. Solving these equations, including proving existence and uniqueness of their solutions, is exceedingly difficult. This is often due to the presence of very singular random forcing, as well as nonlinearities. Various solution theories were established based on different approaches, the most powerful of which is the theory of regularity structures introduced by Hairer around 2013 and further developed by the PI and a few other authors since then. This research will apply the theory, combined with ideas from other areas such as quantum field theory to investigate more SPDE problems. The PI will provide solutions to new important examples of SPDEs, including equations with gauge symmetry and the sine-Gordon equation near criticality. The PI also plans to prove scaling limit results for these singular SPDEs. In particular the PI will study convergence of discrete systems, such as the Glauber dynamics of ferromagnetic systems and directed polymers in random media, to the solutions to these SPDEs in various scaling regimes. The PI will also organize conferences and develop courses to disseminate this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF grant DMS-1712684 entitled “Solution theories and scaling limit problems in stochastic partial differential equations” was awarded when the PI was a Ritt assistant professor at Columbia University, and was later renamed to DMS-1909525 after transfer from Columbia to Wisconsin-Madison in 2018.

a) Intellectual Merit. NSF grant DMS-1712684 was pivotal in the development of the subfield stochastic partial differential equations (SPDE) of probability. The PI and collaborators proved the first result on local well-posedness of singular stochastic PDE that is arbitrarily close to criticality, in the context of sine-Gordon model, using Hairer’s theory of regularity structures; developed new techniques to establish SPDE scaling limits of statistical models such as six vertex, exclusion processes and ferromagnetic models; made significant connections from stochastic analysis to quantum field theory, gauge theory, conformal field theory and geometry. These results not only promoted the development of SPDE theory such as the theory of regularity structures but also built bridges to other areas such as statistical mechanics and quantum physics, thus sparked significant interest from broader communities. 

b) Broader Impacts. NSF grant DMS-1712684 led to discovery and study of a number of models for physical systems such as polymer chains, transport system, traffic flow, magnets with defects, and ice type system. Our study of these models produced applicable predictions to these systems. For example, the PI studied a model for transport system in which identities (such as chemical particles, cars, biological cells) are transported from one place (such as a reservoir) to another through a tunnel. Depending on the densities at the two reservoirs the system exhibits different behaviors. Our study made precise prediction on what happens when the system transits from being stuck or idle to operating at its maximal efficiency. The PI’s results have drawn interest or been applied by physicists in a number of physics papers.

Our article “Some recent progress in singular stochastic PDEs” published on Bulletin of the AMS summarized the current development of this area, and was written assuming minimal knowledge on probability and PDE and thus not only understandable by general mathematical society but also pedagogical to physicists, engineers and financial analysts. 

c) Publications and products. DMS-1712684 / DMS-1909525 supported or partially supported the production of 13 papers and over 300 citations of the PIs work. During these grants the PI has actively disseminated this research through 2 international summer schools, 20 international conferences, and 15 seminars. The PI received the 2017 Axioms Travel Awards during support by DMS-1712684. He has actively participated in professional activities including organizing several conferences and special conference sessions.
